title: 11 All-Natural Ways To Strengthen Your Immune System, From An Immunologist
description: Immunologist Heather Moday, M.D., reveals the most effective ways for boosting the immune system naturally, including mushrooms, vitamin D, and saunas.*
cleaned_text: 11 Ways To Boost Your Immune System Naturally, According To An Immunologist [By Heather Moday, M.D.](/wc/dr-heather-moday) As an immunologist and allergist, I'm often asked, "How can I strengthen my immune system naturally?" In reality, it's about [training our immune system to do its job correctly](https://www.mindbodygreen.com/articles/how-to-train-your-immune-system-from-functional-medicine-expert). That is, we want to be able to fend off the things that can hurt us, while remaining non-reactive to benign things like [pollen](https://www.mindbodygreen.com/articles/the-link-between-inflammation-allergies) and foods. Advertisement The bottom line is that a healthy body is dependent on a strong immune system. There are many ways to perform immune-system upkeep and not just by [avoiding some destructive habits](https://www.mindbodygreen.com/articles/why-do-i-keep-getting-sick), stressors, and toxins but by embracing natural immune supporters and adopting behaviors that encourage immunity. These are some of the key ways I recommend all my patients support their immune function: Take this nutrient triad on a daily basis* Although there are several vitamins and minerals that support our immune system, these three really pack a punch.* Instead of a reactive approach, I recommend you prioritize and take this essential micronutrient trifecta daily to support the critical and numerous functions of your innate and adaptive immune systems.* Along with prioritizing nutrient-dense food sources from our diet, a high-quality immune supplement designed for daily use can be prudent.* - Zinc: Zinc affects multiple aspects of the immune system and even [acts as an antioxidant](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/10801958) [1](#citations)by fighting off free radicals.* It's also a very common nutrient gap worldwide, which is why a supplement can be helpful.* In terms of the diet, rich sources of this essential mineral include meats, seafood, whole grains, dairy, nuts, and seeds. - Vitamin D3: Although you can get a small amount of [vitamin D through sunlight](https://www.mindbodygreen.com/articles/vitamin-d-supplementation-vs-sunshine), there are many factors that impact your ability to get a meaningful amount, (read more about that [here](https://www.mindbodygreen.com/articles/factors-that-make-it-hard-to-get-vitamin-d-from-the-sun)), and thus, many adults don't get the levels of [vitamin D required to modulate the immune system](https://www.mindbodygreen.com/articles/vitamin-d-immunity).* - Vitamin C: Vitamin C is really a powerhouse vitamin and antioxidant for daily immunity.* Suboptimal vitamin C status [has been associated](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/10543583) [2](#citations)with lower immune strength and resilience.* It's also a crucial free-radical scavenger that [significantly protects](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/4069036) [3](#citations)our immune cells as they work hard to defend us.* In addition to incorporating lots of fruits and vegetables in your daily nutrition habits, a [vitamin C supplement](https://www.mindbodygreen.com/articles/best-vitamin-c-supplements)can provide additional immune insurance where gaps may exist.* Summary Advertisement Take a probiotic that has a broad array of species* One of the most important thing one can do to cultivate strong immunity is to start where the majority of the immune system really resides: [the gut](https://www.mindbodygreen.com/articles/signs-of-an-unhealthy-gut). The gut is where about [80% of your immune cells](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/10564096) [4](#citations) hang out, and it's one of the primary locations where our bodies decide what is friend and what is foe. By strengthening our gut health, we are [benefiting our immunity](https://www.mindbodygreen.com/articles/probiotic-for-immunity). Lactobacillus and Bifidobacterium are two of the most important families of [bacteria that populate our gut](https://www.mindbodygreen.com/articles/guide-to-most-common-probiotic-strains-and-what-they-do) from birth, and they have been shown to positively affect our immune health.* Look for a digestive health-focused probiotic that has 30 billion or more colony forming units (total). Remember, these are live organisms, and it pays to spend a little more on a good-quality brand (find our favorites [here)](https://www.mindbodygreen.com/articles/9-best-probiotic-supplements-of-2023-for-your-gut). In addition, your everyday routine is beneficial. I also recommend including plenty of [prebiotic-rich foods](https://www.mindbodygreen.com/articles/prebiotic-rich-foods) in your diet (such as [psyllium husk](https://www.mindbodygreen.com/articles/psyllium-husk-powder-health-benefits-uses-supplements-recipe), larch arabinogalactan, and [Acacia powder](https://www.mindbodygreen.com/articles/acacia-fiber-health-benefits-how-to-use-it)), which help feed the good bacteria in your gut. Summary Advertisement Try colostrum One of the benefits of being breastfed as a baby is the protective antibodies we get from our mother. These antibodies get us through the first years of life while our own immune system is learning the ropes. This is why breastfed individuals are [generally healthier](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/labs/pmc/articles/PMC7830895/) [5](#citations) as they get older. [Colostrum](https://www.mindbodygreen.com/articles/colostrum-powder-effectiveness) is the "first milk" from nursing mammals, and it's a rich source of these protective antibodies, as well as substances with anti-inflammatory properties, like lactoferrin. Luckily, we can harness the power of colostrum even as adults to help maintain a healthy inflammatory response and strengthen our immune system. In powder form from grass-fed cows, goats, and other mammals, it can be mixed into [smoothies and juices](https://www.mindbodygreen.com/articles/easy-smoothies-to-transform-your-morning). Summary Advertisement Incorporate bone broth Our grandmothers knew what they were talking about, seeing as how the [bone broth](https://www.mindbodygreen.com/articles/not-all-bone-broths-are-created-equal-heres-what-to-look-for) industry has exploded. The benefits of drinking and cooking with organic bone broth have far-reaching effects on the immune system. The natural gelatin, [collagen](https://www.mindbodygreen.com/articles/guide-to-collagen-supplements), and amino acids tend to the gut and help support the health of individual immune cells such as lymphocytes.* So, there is definitely good reason to drink homemade chicken soup when dealing with a cold or the flu. Summary Advertisement Investigate fungi Some of the [most powerful](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4684115/) [6](#citations) immune-supporting substances are found in mushrooms. - Reishi: Although not edible, these mushrooms [have powerful](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC1160565/) [7](#citations)antiviral properties. They are best taken as a dried capsule supplement or in a tea or tincture. - Shiitake: The delicious mushroom easily found in grocery stores contains substances called beta-glucans, which [stimulate the immune system](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/22164761) [8](#citations)and strengthen our white blood cells.* - Maitake: My personal favorite, these are also called "Hen of the woods" and are not only delicious but [increase our immune cells' responses.](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/labs/pmc/articles/PMC4202470/) [9](#citations) Summary Harness the power of the sun Immune cells are favorably affected by healthy [vitamin D levels](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/labs/pmc/articles/PMC7680047/) [10](#citations), which can be obtained [in small amounts via the sun](https://www.mindbodygreen.com/articles/factors-that-make-it-hard-to-get-vitamin-d-from-the-sun). In fact, vitamin D deficiency (which affects [29% of U.S. adults](https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/british-journal-of-nutrition/article/vitamin-d-deficiency-and-insufficiency-among-us-adults-prevalence-predictors-and-clinical-implications/44E436843510FE6BDE856D5BCB9C651F) [11](#citations)) is associated with lower immune system functioning. [Soaking up the sunshine safely](https://www.mindbodygreen.com/articles/pros-and-cons-of-different-sources-of-vitamin-d), and spending time in nature are both valuable for overall well-being. However, one of the most [effective ways to raise and maintain your 25(OH)D levels](https://www.mindbodygreen.com/articles/pros-and-cons-of-different-sources-of-vitamin-d) (aka your vitamin D status) is to take a supplement with 5,000 IU [vitamin D3](https://shop.mindbodygreen.com/products/d3?itc_content=31077) in each serving.* Summary Sweat it out in a sauna Several studies show that using an [infrared sauna](https://www.mindbodygreen.com/articles/infrared-saunas-health-benefits) on a regular basis improves the health of our protective white blood cells, and [enhances the immunological defence](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/labs/pmc/articles/PMC3916915/) [12](#citations). In addition, sweating helps rid your body of toxins, helping to maintain a healthy inflammatory response. Summary Eat foods with antimicrobial properties One way to support your immune strength daily is through [a few key superfoods](https://www.mindbodygreen.com/articles/immune-boosting-foods). You can eat these foods on a daily basis, so that you are constantly improving and supporting your immunity. Raw garlic: This superfood has very strong [antimicrobial and antiviral properties](https://www.mindbodygreen.com/articles/how-to-make-fermented-garlic-to-boost-immunity). The potent sulfur compound allicin in garlic is known to helps support a healthy gut. If you're feeling off, start eating one raw garlic clove daily, or use concentrated allicin extract. Oregano oil: This oil has a long history touted for its antimicrobial, antiviral, and antifungal properties. It of research](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/labs/pmc/articles/PMC7536959/) [14](#citations) exists on the benefits of honey as a natural immune supporter, with anti-inflammatory and antimicrobial actions. [Manuka honey](https://www.mindbodygreen.com/articles/manuka-honey-for-acne), and Australia— [has substances](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4837971) [15](#citations) that can speed up th immune response both when eaten and used topically. Summary Get your exercise on Beyond the obvious cardiovascular, mood, and weight management benefits of regular exercise, moderate physical activity can improve our antibody response. It's important not to overtrain, however, as strenuous exercise without recovery days has [been associated with](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S1043466617302922?via%3Dihub) [16](#citations) a lowered immune response, as well as a higher risk of getting hurt. (Try these [cortisol-conscious workouts](https://www.mindbodygreen.com/articles/why-you-need-cortisol-conscious-workouts-if-youre-stressed-out), which are effective without putting too much stress on the body.) Summary Take to your bed [Lack of sleep ](https://www.mindbodygreen.com/articles/what-is-sleep-debt-and-what-can-you-do-about-it)and disruption of the sleep-wake cycle can impact immune health, by lowering the activity of T-cells (a crucial type of immune cell). Studies of identical twins [show](https://academic.oup.com/sleep/article/doi/10.1093/sleep/zsw019/2952682/Transcriptional-Signatures-of-Sleep-Duration) that those with better sleep had a healthier inflammatory and immune response than the those who got less sleep. Aim for seven to eight hours of sleep on a regular basis and avoid all-nighters. If you travel through time zones frequently, use small amounts of melatonin (two to three milligrams) to reset your [circadian rhythm](https://www.mindbodygreen.com/articles/why-your-circadian-rhythm-rules-your-health-exactly-what-to-do-about-it). Summary Manage your stress Too much stress [actually impacts](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/labs/pmc/articles/PMC7882157/) [17](#citations) the immune response by releasing the hormone [cortisol](https://www.mindbodygreen.com/articles/foods-that-reduce-cortisol). Cortisol itself interferes with the ability of specific white blood cells called T-cells to proliferate and get signals from the body. In addition, cortisol also lowers an important antibody called secretory IgA, which lines the respiratory tract and gut and is our first line of defense. In fact, [studies show](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/labs/pmc/articles/PMC8842003/) [18](#citations) that even a short course of meditation can increase levels of IgA (an antibody blood protein that's part of your immune system) and improve immune function. I also highly recommend fostering connection and [gratitude practices](https://www.mindbodygreen.com/articles/showing-your-gratitude)—to help manage stress and promote overall well-being. For both men and women, taking stock of the health of your immune system on a regular basis can not only keep you from getting sick, but it can help you age more gracefully, too. Summary [Heather Moday, M.D.Allergist & Immunologist](/wc/dr-heather-moday) Dr. Heather Moday received her medical degree from [Tulane Medical School](https://medicine.tulane.edu/) in New Orleans. She completed a residency in internal medicine and a fellowship in allergy and immunology. She completed a fellowship in integrative medicine with the Arizona Integrative Medicine program and is board-certified in integrative and holistic medicine. She completed her functional medicine training with the [Institute for Functional Medicine](https://www.functionalmedicine.org/) and the Kalish Functional Medicine Fellowship. She started the Moday Center for Functional and Integrative Medicine in Philadelphia, where she practices both traditional medicine and integrative medicine.
